articles.headline: Coronavirus Layoff Surge Overwhelms Unemployment Offices
articles.snippet: States are trying to beef up skeleton crews to handle a flood of jobless claims while expanding workers’ access to benefits.
articles.abstract: States are trying to beef up skeleton crews to handle a flood of jobless claims while expanding workers’ access to benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The best place to get a job right now might be the unemployment office.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Her Facebook Friends Asked if Anyone Was Actually Sick. She Had an Answer.
articles.snippet: Heaven Frilot is normally a private person. But this is not a normal time. So she and her husband are now the face of the coronavirus for their conservative Louisiana community.
articles.abstract: Heaven Frilot is normally a private person. But this is not a normal time. So she and her husband are now the face of the coronavirus for their conservative Louisiana community.
articles.lead_paragraph: The only thing that should have been different about the first Friday in March was the apple crisp. Heaven Frilot didn’t usually cook at the end of the workweek, instead letting her family snack on leftovers — a roast or pork chops she’d made earlier, maybe — or order pizza. But her 10-year-old son, Ethan, was having a friend over that night, and her husband, Mark, a lawyer, was coming off a crushing week of arbitration. She would bake an apple crisp.

articles.headline: A Torrent of Job Losses Threatens to Overwhelm the U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: New filings for unemployment benefits rose 30 percent last week amid cutbacks and shutdowns over the coronavirus crisis.
articles.abstract: New filings for unemployment benefits rose 30 percent last week amid cutbacks and shutdowns over the coronavirus crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an early sign of the coronavirus pandemic’s devastating impact on American workers, the Labor Department on Thursday reported a 30 percent increase in unemployment claims last week, one of the largest spikes on record.

articles.headline: Search for Coronavirus Vaccine Becomes a Global Competition
articles.snippet: The United States, China and Europe are battling to be the first to find a cure, bringing a nationalist element to a worldwide crisis.
articles.abstract: The United States, China and Europe are battling to be the first to find a cure, bringing a nationalist element to a worldwide crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A global arms race for a coronavirus vaccine is underway.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, David D. Kirkpatrick, Sui-Lee Wee and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: The Coder and the Dictator
articles.snippet: Gabriel Jiménez hated the Venezuelan strongman Nicolás Maduro. But he loved cryptocurrency. When he built the regime a digital coin, he nearly paid with his life.
articles.abstract: Gabriel Jiménez hated the Venezuelan strongman Nicolás Maduro. But he loved cryptocurrency. When he built the regime a digital coin, he nearly paid with his life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just after midnight one Tuesday in early 2018, the vice president of Venezuela commandeered the nation’s TV airwaves. Looking composed despite the hour, in a blue suit and red tie, he announced that the government was about to make history by becoming the first on Earth to sell its own cryptocurrency. It would be known as the Petro.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Ana Vanessa Herrero

articles.headline: Coronavirus and Poverty: A Mother Skips Meals So Her Children Can Eat
articles.snippet: Americans with tight financial resources have fewer options as they navigate coronavirus closures and layoffs.
articles.abstract: Americans with tight financial resources have fewer options as they navigate coronavirus closures and layoffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRENHAM, Texas — With her six hungry children in the car, Summer Mossbarger was one of the first in line for lunch at the drive-through. Not at a fast-food restaurant, but outside Alton Elementary School.

articles.headline: Coronavirus Stimulus Package Spurs a Lobbying Gold Rush
articles.snippet: Some industries are in dire need of a bailout. Others see a rare chance to win special breaks at a moment when the fiscal spigots are open.
articles.abstract: Some industries are in dire need of a bailout. Others see a rare chance to win special breaks at a moment when the fiscal spigots are open.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Restaurants say they need $325 billion in federal assistance. Boeing wants $60 billion. The travel industry has requested $250 billion and manufacturers are seeking $1.4 trillion in loans to deal with the economic devastation being wrought by the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Catie Edmondson and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Trump Resists Pressure to Use Wartime Law to Mobilize Industry in Virus Response
articles.snippet: The president insisted he has used the Defense Production Act, but said at a briefing that “we are literally being besieged” by companies “that want to do the work and help our country.”
articles.abstract: The president insisted he has used the Defense Production Act, but said at a briefing that “we are literally being besieged” by companies “that want to do the work and help our country.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his advisers have resisted calls from congressional Democrats and a growing number of governors to use a federal law that would mobilize industry and provide badly needed resources against the coronavirus spread, days after the president said he would consider using that authority.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers, Maggie Haberman and Ana Swanson
